title: macbook air review keyboard magic butterfly apple price
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Apple's new laptop is familiarly sleek and returns with an unrivalled typing experienceApple has just revealed a new MacBook Air. It looks outwardly near-identical to the current model, but it offers better value, increased storage and faster performance. But even these things are not the game-changer: that’s the new keyboard.The pricing first: where the previous MacBook Air, on sale until just days ago, cost £1,099 and came with 128GB of internal storage, the entry-level Air is now £100 less, £999, and has 256GB of storage. There’s also a 512GB model available, with a faster processor, for £1,299. There are still lots of laptops out there for much less money, but this price represents good value. Note that Apple has education pricing for those in class as students or teachers, so it’s possible to get that price even lower if you qualify.The look is the same as before: sleek and classy. It comes in three colours, silver, space grey and gold. The space grey is the best: solid and businesslike without looking boring, though the gold, warm with a peachy hint to it, is also a head-turner.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe build quality of the MacBook Air is exceptional, an all-aluminium casing that’s sculpted to the slimmest of edges to make it easy to pick up. Like all MacBooks, and unlike many other laptops, you can open it with one hand, the build is so perfectly balanced. Other machines require a finger to hold down the keyboard as you open the lid or the whole thing swings up as it opens.This MacBook Air continues to have a power button with Touch ID built in – a fingerprint scanner that ensures your computer screen locks when you’re away from it and only unlocks to your finger. Apple Watch wearers can also use their smart timepiece to unlock the MacBook Air, which is cool. touches to navigate between windows, scroll through documents and so on.Like every other current Mac laptop, there are only two kinds of socket: a headphone jack and Thunderbolt USB-C for power or to connect accessories. The Air has two Thunderbolt USB-C ports. For other connections, such as USB-A, you’ll need an adaptor. That’s not always convenient, though it gets easier all the time as more accessories switch to USB-C, and it helps to keep the Air thin.The MacBook Air has been preposterously slim and light since it was first unveiled by Steve Jobs in 2008 when the then-CEO slid it out of an envelope to an admiring crowd. It was so much thinner and lighter than the competition that it drew gasps of excitement. Over the next decade it slipped behind, especially in terms of the screen resolution, though that’s been fixed. Now, the 13in display is bright, rich and superbly high-resolution.Apple releases iPad with 3D scanner and a trackpadApple and Netflix pull out of SXSW over coronavirus fearsAnd then there’s the new keyboard. Apple keyboards were traditionally outstanding, using a scissor-switch mechanism, with lots of travel and a great feel. Then, a few years ago, Apple changed to a whole new system, using a butterfly mechanism. The first-generation of this was quite noisy, but this was overcome in subsequent versions. But then, problems arose which led to keyboards being replaced as users complained that there wasn’t the same reliability.Last year, on the MacBook Pro 16in, Apple introduced the Magic Keyboard – a name taken from its desktop wireless keyboard – which changed everything. The new keys were quieter, more stable and had more travel – a full 1mm. That’s not quite as much as the keys moved before the butterfly landed, when it was 1.2mm. But it was enough, and it was a revelation.It’s the same here. Using the new keyboard subtly transforms the typing experience. It’s not that the butterfly keys were bad: unless they failed, they worked well and were comfortable to use.But as soon as you use the new Magic Keyboard, you recognise how comfortable and inviting it is. The downside is it’s quite hard to go back. Having typed this review on the MacBook Air keys, I picked up a previous Air to make a comparison. As soon as I started typing, my fingers told me I was missing the new experience. The keys on the old Air, which I had used happily before, just couldn’t match the luxurious and satisfying feel of the new one. The gentle scoop on the top of each key that helps your fingers find the right place to touch, the crisper inidual backlighting to make typing in a less bright room a breeze and the clearer lettering on each key – all of which are small, subtle improvements that Apple has made with the Magic Keyboard – add up to something big.The processor has been improved on the latest models with a 1.1GHz dual-core Core i3 processor on the £999 model and a 1.1GHz quad-core Core i5 chip on the £1,299 version.In practical terms, this means that the Air is a real performer. Not that it was a slouch before, but it handles tasks easily. It’s true, the MacBook Pro is still the go-to laptop for those doing advanced video processing or running other power-hungry programs. But the Air is now very fast and effective. To the extent that many customers may ask whether they really need to spend £1,299 on the entry-level 13in MacBook Pro rather than a £999 MacBook Air that isn’t that far off. Sure, there are other extras in the Pro range, like the spiffy Touch Bar instead of function keys, and four Thunderbolt USB-C sockets instead of two on the Air, for instance.Battery life on the MacBook Air is exemplary: it just goes on and on all day where other laptops, including some MacBook Pro models, don’t last as long. It’s so good that you may not even think about checking how much charge is left in the battery. It gives a great feeling of peace of mind.The new MacBook Air is available for order now, with deliveries starting next week. It represents a big step forward for the super-slim Apple laptop, combining sumptuous good looks with real performance and, above all, an unbeatably appealing keyboard.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: oyster whale projects sustainability lottery funding
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The National Lottery Heritage Fund announced cash for five new projects focusing on Scotland’s seas and inland waterways and their habitatsProjects to restore native oyster beds and improve a whale trail are among those sharing in £1.33m of lottery funding.The National Lottery Heritage Fund has announced cash for five new projects focusing on the sustainability of Scotland’s seas and inland waterways and their habitats.They include £216,400 for a project to restore native oysters on a sea loch on the mid-Argyll coast by growing up to one million of them over five years to create a self-sustaining population.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOrca sets record with 5,000-mile journey from Iceland to BeirutUnprecedented number of critically endangered blue whales recordedLive whale washes up on Cornwall beachHow to eat out sustainablyCharity organisation Sea Wilding will be working with volunteer group Craignish Restoration of Marine and Coastal Habitats (CROMACH) to grow the oysters in floating baskets to be moved to trial seabed sites that were once widespread in the loch.Another grant, of £443,000, will be used to redevelop Edinburgh attraction Dynamic Earth’s Ocean Galleries into a “contemporary immersive exhibition” designed to inspire and educate more than 250,000 people a year about Scotland’s deep-sea heritage.Caroline Clark, Scotland director of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, said: “As we celebrate Scotland’s Year of Coasts and Waters, there has never been a better time to raise awareness of the important role our marine heritage has in the future of a sustainable environment.“Not only is the direct conservation we fund vitally important but we hope that through our projects there will be increased awareness of how and why we need to change our behaviours in order to protect our future.”Meanwhile, a £250,000 funding boost will help the Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust Centre in Tobermory on Mull be redeveloped as the Gateway to the Hebridean Whale Trail, which links 33 sites across the west coast of Scotland.Coronavirus outbreak exposing ‘precarious nature of UK welfare system’The project will strengthen the Hebridean Whale Trail, including new interpretation in the centre, films and a programme of activities to educate visitors, in both English and Gaelic, on the marine heritage of the Hebrides.Elsewhere on the west coast, the natural habitat of the Plock parkland near the Skye Bridge will be improved to provide an important green space for the local community with the help of £196,100 award.A £228,100 grant to the Gateway to Gigha project will help protect the natural and cultural heritage of the island through a new community initiative encouraging more people to travel without their car and providing foot and cycle access to the island’s historic sites.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘Emergency disease outbreak will often be adequate justification for taking exceptional measures,’ MPs sayEnhanced measures to curb the coronavirus&nbspoutbreak will “significantly curtail” fundamental freedoms in Britain – but can be legally justified, MPs have said.Parliament’s Joint Committee on Human Rights&nbspsaid it would be thoroughly scrutinising new laws and action taken by authorities.“Some measures could significantly curtail inidual rights,” MPs wrote in a briefing paper issued on Thursday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“There are other practical and economic impacts on iniduals who cannot work due to self-isolating, or due to sickness – some of these measures will affect certain groups more significantly than others. &nbspHow to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?It came as the government formally announced details of an Emergency Coronavirus Bill setting out measures aimed at slowing the spread and supporting the NHS and workers.Police have already been given new powers to detain anyone with suspected symptoms and force them to undergo testing or be quarantined, although senior officers insisted they would “not be used willy nilly”.Amid rumours of a nationwide “lockdown”, Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said the government was ready to take “incredibly tough decisions” but had no immediate plans to shut down restaurants or force people off the streets.The Joint Committee on Human Rights said any action must comply with both international law and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) but added: “An emergency disease outbreak will often be an adequate justification for taking exceptional measures provided that such measures are justified and proportionate in the circumstances.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. The government needs to protect the right to life and at the same time consider the impact on human rights as it strives to protect the country in this unprecedented time.”The committee said quarantine and self-isolation had an impact on the right to liberty and right to life, while a potential ban on public gatherings affected freedom of assembly and association, and school closures hit the right to education.Restricting people’s ability to work has a “disproportionate impact” on the self-employed and other groups, while the impact on small businesses engages the “right to peaceful enjoyment of one’s possessions”.The committee said that any future moves to prioritise or ration healthcare must be “justifiable and non-discriminatory”, and that the prevention of timely funerals could violate freedom of religion.Members said the government must consider the wellbeing of people held in prisons, immigration detention centres and mental health units, as well as the right to&nbspjustice – after new trials of more than three days were stopped.The committee warned that homeless people and those in temporary accommodation will find it difficult to comply with any formal instruction to self-isolate.It called for evidence to be submitted on the steps taken to ensure the government’s plans comply with human rights and to address the impact on groups that will be title: eu nationals settlement scheme home office settled status brexit
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Home Office refuses people EU&nbspsettled status on grounds of&nbspeligibility&nbspfor first timeHundreds of EU nationals have been told they don’t have the right to stay in the UK after applying for post-Brexit immigration status, figures show.The latest statistics on the government’s EU settlement scheme, published on Thursday, show 300 people have been refused settled status. These iniduals will not have a right to live in Britain after the deadline of June 2021, unless they successfully appeal the decision.The number remains proportionately small, as there have been nearly 3 million applications processed overall, but it marks a considerable jump from the previous monthly figures, when just seven people had been refused.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAt that point the refusals were all on the grounds of criminality, but most of the latest refusals were due to issues around eligibility –&nbspusually because the applicant has been unable to provide the relevant&nbspdocumentary&nbspevidence.While the number is still proportionately low, campaigners have raised alarm at the sudden increase, and it is likely to prompt concern around difficulties more vulnerable people face when obtaining evidence.Charity helping children in care stay in UK has to stop taking casesEU settlement scheme delays leave people unable to get jobsNine out of 10 EU settlement scheme appeals successful, data showsWithout physical proof of our status, EU citizens like me live in fearThe Home Office said officials had made every attempt to obtain the necessary evidence before refusing applications, and that decisions to refuse were not taken lightly and signed off at a high level.Maike Bohn, co-founder of campaign group&nbspthe3million, told The Independent she was concerned by the fact that while there had been no refusals on eligibility grounds before February 2020, there was now a sharp rise.“This is hard to explain. We urgently need more explanation from the Home Office as to why those cases have been refused,” she said. “It is concerning that as soon as the UK left the EU we see people being refused settled status.”Christopher Desira, immigration solicitor at Seraphus law firm, said there were likely to be more and more refusals beyond criminality grounds, which may worry a lot of people in uncommon family arrangements, which tend to be the most complex applications.&nbspHe also raised alarm over the gaps in free outreach and advice services that are likely to form due to the coronavirus outbreak, which may cause problems for those receiving requests for further information from the Home Office, but not know how to respond, and called on the Home Office to pause any refusals until the emergency is over.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLiberal Democrat home affairs spokesperson Christine Jardine called on the government to back the Private Members’ Bill she tabled last month that would guarantee the rights of EU citizens in the UK.Home Office presides over 100 data breaches in EU settlement schemeShe said: “EU citizens in the UK have been living under a cloud of uncertainty for far too long. They are our families and friends, our colleagues and carers. They must have the right to stay.&nbspEven before the coronavirus crisis, we were warning that tens of thousands of EU citizens will be left without settled status when the Conservative government’s arbitrary deadline hits next year.“That would leave thousands of people effectively undocumented and at risk of eviction, detention and even deportation. It will be a new Windrush scandal on an even bigger scale.”The Home Office figures show that overall, there have been more than 3.34 million applications to the scheme up to the end of February 2020.Minister for future borders and immigration Kevin Foster said: “EU citizens have made huge contributions to our country. It’s good news over three million have now been granted status and will be able to continue to call the UK home for decades to come.”Tory MP admits EU settlement scheme sometimes 'doesn't work as well as we expect'The department&nbspsaid it had&nbspa wide range of support was&nbspavailable online, over the phone and in person to help EU citizens apply for settled status.Earlier this month, the department announced a further £8m of funding to award 57 charities to help vulnerable EU citizens apply, on top of £9m announced for the same cause last April.However many charities in receipt of the original funding said they had been forced to cut back on their services due to uncertainty as to whether the funding would continue beyond the month of March – accusing the Home Office of leaving the announcement until the “last minute”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: not time discredit government coronavirus strategy
story: Instead, a handful of broadcasters used precious air time to promote a motley crew of “scientists” desperately hoping to make their names discrediting the Government’s strategy.To those who don’t understand virology, not taking the same draconian measures as other countries may seem odd.But the Prime Minister is acting on the advice of Sir Patrick Vallance and Chris Whitty — eminent doctors ideally equipped to deal with the pandemic.Of course, their superior expertise shouldn’t exempt them from all scrutiny.And, given the stakes, the Government MUST publish the details of its modelling to put minds at rest and give expert virologists a chance to have their say.But puffed-up PhD students with an axe to grind are a far cry from professional epidemiologists.And British broadcasters should know better than to let them spread panic.ACCESS to education is one of the pillars of a civilised society.But because schools are excluding weaker pupils to avoid poor results harming their position in the league tables, a growing number of children are denied that basic right.The consequences of this folly are enormous.It’s estimated that every year-group of permanently excluded pupils costs us £.billion extra on education, health and welfare benefits.And, just as worryingly,  per cent of children in young offender institutions had been excluded while  per cent of prisoners were suspended or excluded.We get that children who struggle academically can be tough on over-stretched teachers.But education shouldn’t be about survival of the fittest.And it’s often the weakest pupils who need school most.Dumping them on the scrapheap of society isn’t fair on anyone.AMID horror and uncertainty, British people are displaying extraordinary kindness, camaraderie and bravery.Each time the Government announces it’s taking another step to keep us safe, Brits have demonstrated that they are listening — and understand the gravity of the situation.Instead of complaining about missed holidays and football games, they’ve quickly and quietly got on with what needs to be done. Shopkeepers — worrying about their own futures — have given out free hand sanitiser and tinned goods to elderly locals.Neighbours have rallied around those most at risk from the disease.This — not needless shelf-clearing — is Britain at its best. Our journalists strive for accuracy title: uk coronavirus lockdown
story: CORONAVIRUS is forcing countries into lockdown and the UK could follow suit with the capital city of London the first to do so.This draconian move involves restricting the movement of residents and only allowing people to leave home to attend essential work, purchase food or medicine - go to a hospital.Despite PM Boris Johnson describing the pandemic as the worst public health crisis for a generation, there has been no plans so far for the UK to go into lockdown. But this could change in the coming days.Health Secretary Matt Hancock will table the Emergency Coronavirus Bill setting out measures aimed at slowing the spread and supporting the NHS and workers in the Commons on Thursday.The legislation will be presented as the Army prepares to help out in the crisis and Londoners faced the prospect of a lockdown in the coming daysFollowing the advice of experts, the UK has said it will be adopting a staged response which includes daily briefings to the public.Ministers have said it is important to get the timing right for stricter measures.London may be facing a coronavirus lockdown soon. Pubs, restaurants, cinemas, theatres, leisure centres and gyms are reportedly set to shut.  Sources close to City Hall say the Government is preparing fresh laws to allow this.Measures include stopping Londoners leaving their homes except to go to the supermarket or pharmacy, The Sun was told.Downing Street said ministers could even use existing laws to keep people in isolation for their own safety.A UK lockdown does look to be inevitable in the near future, as the number of cases and deaths increase.It could mean elderly people being forced by law to stay inside and for people who are under  to travel to only travel to workit cannot be closed “Lockdown” actually isnt a technical term used by public health officials, it is often referred to as “mass quarantines, where residents are forced or advised to stay at home.Although the UK seems to be moving slower than other countries in its response to Covid-, preventative measures have been put in place, with action plans ready to enforcethe situation gets worse.With a major epidemic in the UK expected, the government is exploring ways to delay the spread of coronavirus and reduce the amount of people affected when the pandemic hits its peak.Englands education secretary will be meeting headteachers to discuss the next step for schools and the government have confirmed ver s will be told to stay home in the coming weeks.Last week, Nicola Sturgeon revealed after a cobra meeting, attended by Boris Johnson, that the UK had moved from the delay to the contain phase as the situation remains to be closely monitored.The government has said that during the delay phase:These steps are being implemented to hopefully, signicantly reduce the number of infections and deaths by up to a third.If the number of cases increase, new measures such as forcing people to stay in quarantine and troops being deployed to support emergency services could be introduced.In addition to this, the UK, along with Japan, the eurozone, Canada, and Switzerland have joined forces with the US Central Bank to prevent coronavirus causing a global recession.Interest rates have been cut to zero and a bn stimulus programme has been launched.  The list of countries on lockdown is rapidly growing as the virus continues to spread at an alarming rate.The majority of the countries in lockdown are in Europe, which is the epicentre of the global coronavirus pandemic, according to the World Health Organization.This is as apart from China, alarmingly, Europe has more reported cases and deaths of Covid-, than the rest of the world combined.The full list of all countries on lockdown are as followsOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: trust health service staff coronavirus
story: All along he has followed the best advice of our foremost experts on ­epidemics. They said that would evolve as the situation worsened — and yesterday it was toughened dramatically.National unity is key. We must take to heart the self-isolation and lockdowns — both for those already with symptoms and those without. Likewise the “advice” not to go to pubs, restaurants or cinemas.Our lives will be very dferent for months. Britain will barely resemble the country we love. But we can all play our part in seeing off this catastrophe, minimising the disease’s spread and giving the NHS every chance to save lives.The Sun will raise just one doubt:It still seems inconsistent that families must avoid non-essential social contact, but continue packing the children off to school. We know the NHS would be hit hardhealth workers stayed home to look after their kids. But a school skeleton staff could surely supervise them.Only the wartime generation has experienced a crisis this grave. We have to put our faith politically in the newly elected government tasked with facing it down — and the experts around them.Even more importantly we must trust our health service and back its magnicent and selfless staff. You can do that today by emailing iloveNHS@the-sun or by using the form below. We’ll print your messages.The NHS will need every ounce of support the nation can give, evenit just means dutully staying put in our homes.  THE six days since the Budget seem like ten years.Chancellor Rishi Sunak’s admirable debut last Wednesday is all but irrelevant. Its apparently huge bailouts to mitigate the virus will be nowhere near enough. Its growth forecasts are toast.Britain’s decisive response, including the Bank of England slashing the base rate hours earlier, was praised around the world. Others followed suit. But vastly more will now be needed.Evenit lasts no more than a few months — still a big— Covid- is a gargantuan shock to the global economy.Hundreds of thousands of healthy businesses here face oblivion. Their workers may face the dole. Major ­airlines could go bust within weeks.The Government will have to borrow staggering sums to keep them afloat — dishing out grants, tax breaks, business rates relief, interest-free loans, boosted sick pay and more.But we will add this: This is a ­calamity we must ALL face together.If corporations make staff take the pain while fatcat execs sail through it financially unscathed, there will be hell to pay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus pubs closing shut
story: PUBS face a bleak future along with restaurants, bars, shops, clubs and gyms following Boris Johnsons public address this evening. On Friday, March , Boris ordered ALL of them across the country to close TONIGHT.Pubs in London and the rest of the UK will close tonight as soon as they reasonable can along with gyms, cafes, theatres, clubs, bars, shops, cinemas and restaurants.Up until Fridays announcement people had only been told to steer clear of them, rather than shutting pubs and bars completely.A Number  spokesman said: We have been clear about the importance of social distancing and the need for people, especially in vulnerable groups and in other age groups, to do so.We have been clear about our guidance around social gatherings and again we have asked the public to do what we have asked the public to do.A number of European countries, including Ireland, Italy and Spain, have gone into lockdown to limit the spread of coronavirus, ordering all pubs and non-essential shops and centres to be closed.People were reportedly still flocking to pubs across the country despite the pleas for social distancing to avoid the spread of deadly coronavirus.Pictures showed boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars as they continued to flout government advice and put each other at risk.The pub-goers have been slammed on social media.One user wrote: Shocking isn’t it!  Some London pubs are packed. Dangerous irresponsible idiocy.Another fumed: People arent exercising social distancing, bars are packed! Please Boris, for the love of God... and your people... shut the pubs!Boris Johnson was joined by the Chancellor Rishi Sunak who unveiled an emergency package aimed at protecting workers jobs and wages, as they face hardship in the fight against the coronavirus pandemic.The Prime Minister said that he is confident that the UK economy is going to bounce back, but that the speed of our eventual recovery depends on our collective ability to get on top of the virus now.Mr Johnson added, We are strengthening the measures announced on Wednesday.We need now to push down further on that curb of transmission between us.We are telling cafes, pubs, bars and restaurants to close tonight, as soon as they reasonably can, and not to open tomorrow.He explained that take out services will still be provided.The Prime Minister also said that gyms and leisure centres will also be closing.Some may be tempted to go out tonight, and I say to you please dont. You can still be a carrier of the disease and pass it on to others. We want you to stay at home.Rishi Sunak said: Our planned economic response will be one of the most comprehensive in the world.He addressed the fact that people are worried about money and jobs, and spoke of a collective national effort with a role for everyone to play.Mr Sunak explained that for the first time ever, the government will step in to help pay peoples wages, and any employer in the country will be eligible.Employers will be able to contact HMRC for a grant.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rishi sunak coronavirus economy meltdown
story: Some have already lost their jobs. Others must now give theirs up to look after their kids, with schools closing.It may be hard for politicians to grasp, but many ordinary people have no savings to tide them over.They are broke NOW. They need to feed themselves and their families NOW.Not at the weekend. Not next week.Even those not yet made redundant by this global economic collapse are petried about how bad this could get.The pub industry alone says hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost imminently without immediate help.Other governments have stepped in. Why has ours been so slow Devising a new system to get tens of billions in lost wages into the right hands is complex. We get that.We also think the “universal income” idea is an ill-considered and permanently ruinous fix.But promises, and a temporary ban on evicting renters, won’t quell the fear.This virus is not the fault of the workers, nor the Government whose draconian restrictions are sound.But with the economy in total meltdown, only the Government now can get Britain paid.Do it today, Rishi.CLOSING schools was grimly inevitable but right. It always seemed odd to keep them open while telling everyone to stay home.The Government must fulfil its pledge to ensure kids on free school meals are fully funded to get fed.We pay tribute to the NHS staff, delivery drivers and social carers whose often low-paid work is so essential that their children WILL still be looked after in school.And our hearts go out to the teenagers whose GCSEs and A-levels will be postponed indefinitely.This is an unprecedented nightmare, blighting their childhoods.We can only help each other endure it.IMAGINE the evil of using a deadly ­pandemic to spread fake news furthering your political or commercial agenda.It should no longer shock us after the Salisbury poisonings.But Kremlin trolls are sowing panic online to undermine the West’s Covid- strategies.Let’s remember that, next time our leaders have to make nice with Putin at the G.Meanwhile, conspiracy cranks say hand sanitiser causes cancer — and charlatans claim their “yoghurt suppositories” or vitamin pills “cure” the virus.Where do they do this with near impunity  That’s right . . .On Facebook, which talks such a good game about policing its site — but is always found wanting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: paramedic sainsburys shop empty shelves coronavirus
story: A PARAMEDIC out saving lives all day was pictured amongst empty shelves  — after supermarkets were ransacked as soon as they opened yesterday.Stores have asked police to help stop shoppers “acting like savages”.Hordes of selfish Brits gatecrashed so-called “grey hours” set aside for the old, vulnerable and emergency workers.PM Boris Johnson appealed for the panic buying to stop. He said “There is no reason for shops to be empty. Everybody understands why people are buying stuff, but please be reasonable. Be considerate and thoughtful of others as you do it.”Ministers temporarily tore up competition laws so supermarkets can work together to keep their shelves stocked.They could share stock, staff and delivery vans and work together to decide to shut certain stores and pool resources.Restrictions on the number of hours delivery drivers can work have been suspended. And the p charge on plastic bags has been waived for online shopping to speed up deliveries.Sue Johnson, , said she was pushed out of the way at am by burly men at Sainsbury’s in Sydenham, South London.Make a list of meals you could cook or have and then work out what you would need to buy.If the UK does enter a lockdown situation then supermarkets and pharmacies will remain open.You will still be able to visit them - unless youre self isolating.Remember, family and friends will be able to bring you supplies should you not be able to leave the house.Weve created a guide on how to stockpile for a two-week isolation.Idiots were seen stealing pasta from foodbanks. title: spot camouflaged pets hiding house pics
story: These camouflaged cats and disguised dogs are hard to spot - even when youre looking directly at them. Some of these creatures seem to be using their likeness to soft furnishings to take over sofas and beds.One moggy has hidden itself next to rolled towels in a bathroom, while a fluffy cat is barely distinguishable as it stretches out on a cosy-looking rug.Many owners have taken to social media to share hilarious images of their pets after millions of people were ordered to work from home during the coronavirus outbreak.The sweet snaps show cats and dogs will do anything to distract their owners - including, as these photos reveal, temporarily going missing by disguising themselves as blankets and sofas.

title: family urinate bottles flat kazakhstan

title: boris says we can send coronavirus packing in 12 weeks if we follow strict rules
story: BRITAIN can send coronavirus packing in just  weekswe all follow strict new rules, Boris Johnson vowed today.In an impassioned plea to the nation tonight the PM stressed that the whole country could be over the worst of the crisis in three monthsthey bucked up and did their duty now - before its too late.At a Downing Street press conference he begged Brits to stop going out to the pub, practise social distancing and work from homethey can.Please, please follow that advice, he told the public, as he thanked them for their valiant efforts so far.Offering the nation a ray of hope in some of Britains darkest days since the war, he promised hard-hit Brits that there WAS light at the end of the tunnel.With ruthless, determined, collective action and scientic progress, we will succeed, the PM said.If we do this together, we will save many thousands of lives.Speaking just an hour after the Queen urged the country to do their bit to tackle the bug, he stressed we can curb the tide within the next  weeks and stressed he was confident we can send coronavirus packing in this country.But he warned: Onlywe take the steps we have outlined.Boris pleaded with people not to panic-buy goods too - after days of shops being stripped bare by Brits grabbing as much stock as they can.The dramatic sweeping measures came as:The PM again refused to rule out shutting pubs and restaurants to try to stop the spread, but made no hint as to whether it was on the way soon.We will do it very much by the science and whether we think the advice given is working, he said.If we feelit isnt working and we need to bring in tougher measures... nothing is ruled out.And he again vowed that a package of vital measures for helping working Brits up and down the country was on the way.Boris said this evening: We are going to look after the people who really suffer, we will be directing our support to them first, the people first.The PM stressed that the first patients had started a randomised trial to try and help cure them of the disease.And he promised to ramp up testing to a whopping , PER DAY in future - yet gave no details on how that would happen. Negotiations are underway to buy a new game-changing antibody tests which will tellanyone has had the virus too, he said.If it works, we will buy literally hundreds of thousands of these kits as soon as practical, he promised.After claims from Nicola Sturgeon that more stringent measures on London could be on the way, the PM vowed that no one would be told not to leave their home as is the case in Italy and France.He promised: We are not going to be telling people that under no circumstances they should go to work.There is no prospect of us wanting to stop public transport in London.He also used his daily address to beg employers not to fire their staff as help was coming for them tomorrow.It came after Boris and the Government laid out sweeping new emergency laws to crack down on every aspect of le in Britain today.NHS staff and police will have the power to detain people for up to  hours and force them to be tested for Covid-.The sweeping laws give them to power to order them not to attend work or to stay in isolation, or ban them from travelling.And they will face a £, finethey dont comply.The -page bill will allow for more phone and video hearings in court so the justice system can keep going.Officials will be able to suspend all plane and ship arrivals at airports or ports or there aren’t enough staff to maintain border security.Morgues could be expanded and inquests stripped back in order to try and deal with extra deaths.It also enacts pension changes so retired doctors and nurses can come back into the NHS easily without their retirement cash suffering.The emergency powers will be able to be switched on and switched offand when needed - for up to two years.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said: “We are doing everything we can to protect lives and support the NHS, guided by the best scientists and clinicians in the world.“The new measures we will be introducing in the Emergency Coronavirus Bill this week will only be used when it is absolutely necessary and must be timed to maximise their effectiveness, but crucially they give the government the powers it needs to protect lives.The plans also included:Meanwhile, Downing Street denied that the capital would be put into lockdown - title: nurse tearful plea coronavirus panic buying
story: A CRITICAL care nurse broke down in tears as she pleaded for people to stockpiling after she was unable to buy basic foods at the end of her -hour sht.Dawn Bilbrough, , from York, made the emotional appeal in a minute-long video in which she begs: “Please just stop it.”Sitting in her car she admits to having a cry in the supermarket after failing to get hold of any food.She said: “I’ve just come out the supermaket and there’s no fruit and veg. title: defeat coronavirus nation play part
story: We all need rapidly to get a grip.The Government’s advice, backed by its scientists, has been clear enough: Avoid pubs and restaurants, where the virus can so easily spread.Stop the brainless panic-buying and hoarding which strips shelves of essentials ALL of us need — especially OAPs, exhausted NHS workers and the low-paid.Yet some pubs remain packed, notably in London where two-thirds of the latest deaths occurred.Some young people think a pint is worth the risk.Old folk reckon Britain saw off the Nazis, so they won’t be cowed by a microscopic bug.We can understand it . . . but both attitudes are delusional and irresponsible.It won’t just be their problemthey catch Covid-.They could infect an old or sick person, who dies.And the NHS will have to cope with all of it.People must stay at home.And though The Sun has always been a friend to our pubs, Boris Johnson must ignore his liberal instincts and shut themneed be.Supermarkets, meanwhile, insist the food supply is perfectly adequate IF people shop sensibly and considerately.But queues snake around the block at dawn.Selfish shoppers buy enough loo roll, pasta and medicine for months.It is insane, unnecessary and must stop. title: britains brexit negotiator self isolating after showing symptoms of coronavirus
story: BRITAINS Brexit negotiator David Frost has been forced to self-isolate after showing symptoms of coronavirus.The deadly virus has wreaked havoc on both sides of the trade talks, after EU negotiator Michel Barnier tested positive for COVID- yesterday.Mr Frost is following government advice and isolating himself after displaying symptoms for the virus, according to Bloomberg.His isolation follows swtly on from Mr Barniers twitter announcement on Thursday afternoon that he had tested positive for coronavirus.The two Brexit negotiators have not seen each other since the last round of trade talks two weeks ago.Another round of talks were scheduled to take place in London this week but were quickly postponed after COVID- tightened its grip on Britain and Europe.The number of confirmed cases in the UK skyrocketed yesterday for , with  deaths.Europe closed down the borders of the previously pass-port free Schengen Area to bar entry to international travellers.The death toll in Europe has surpassed Asia.It comes as:Boris Johnson has refused to extend the transition period even in light of growing crisis.He said earlier this week that the end of the transition period was enshrined in law and he would not consider changing it.The UK formally left the EU on January  but will continue to follow the blocs rules until December . Both sides have said that talks will continue through other ways, including video conference, to keep steam behind the crucial discussions.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.

title: invisible coronavirus enemy unmasked microscope images erupts human cells
story: THESE chilling images reveal the reality of the deadly coronavirus - which has killed more than , people worldwide.The virus can be seen erupting out from the surface of human cells which were cultured in a laboratory and taken from a patient in America by the US National Institutes of Health.Scientists scanned the bug which causes Covid- under an electron microscope and colorised the pictures so they could dferentiate the virus to heathy cells.In particular, the scans clearly show the spikes on the outer edge of the virus particles which give coronaviruses their name - as corona means crown or halo in Latin.The scientists also discovered from the scans that the virus that causes Covid- is stable for several hours to days in aerosols and on surfaces.They found that the bug was detectable in aerosols for up to three hours, up to four hours on copper, up to  hours on cardboard and up to two to three days on plastic and stainless steel.The new disease emerged in China in December and has never been seen in humans before the current outbreak.Its been called severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus by the World Health Organisation and causes an illness thats now named Covid-.The new strain is thought to have jumped from bats to humans, via a possible but unknown animal, in the Chinese city of Wuhan.So far, there have been more than , deaths worldwide from the outbreak, while over , have been confirmed as ill.In the UK alone, the death toll stands at , while the number of those diagnosed with Covid- is at ,.Currently, there is no vaccine to protect people against the virus.Tap to see where Covid- is near you Antibiotics do not help, as they do not work against viruses - title: coronavirus hotspot midlands
story: A SECOND coronavirus hotspot has emerged in the Midlands - with the Health Secretary today warning we dont know why.Thirty-two deaths have been recorded in Midlands hospitals - accounting for about  per cent of the fatalities in the UK that today hit .The death toll in the Midlands is more than recorded across all of the seven National Health Service England regions apart from London which has recorded  deaths - more than a third.Coronavirus cases in the Midlands hit  last night, the third highest behind London and the South East.Speaking today, Health Secretary Matt Hancock said authorities were doing everything possible to find out why the hotspot had emerged.He said: There is a hotspot, not as big as in London, but there is a hotspot in the Midlands.Its something that were looking at very, very closely to find out why, frankly.I mean, the spread of a disease like this does tend to be in areas of hotspot and then broadening out from them.Yesterday, eight more coronavirus fatalities in the West Midlands alone were reported including three at the Royal Wolverhampton NHS Trust, two by the Dudley Group NHS Foundation Trust, two by Sandwell and West Birmingham NHS Trust and one by University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust.But despite the high death toll, Brits were still seen partying just this week to mark St Patricks Day in Birmingham.Students were pictured dancing on chairs and singing despite the government issuing pleas for Brits to avoid all non-essential contact.Shoppers in the Midlands have also been among those rushing to the shops to panic-buy supplies despite authorities desperately pleading be reasonable.Birmingham is the second largest city in the UK with about .million people in the city. A total of about . million live in the metropolitan area.The multicultural community is also one of the biggest travel hubs thanks to the East Midlands Airport and the Midlands Rail Hub.And its hub came into high demand already during the coronavirus crisis with a plane carrying  Brit nationals who were on board a virus-riddled cruise, the Grand Princess, were flown into Birmingham Airport earlier this month.During the financial year of  , the University Hospitals Birmingham NHS Foundation Trust was the busiest hospital provider.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.And Hancock today vowed to use the nations resources to tackle the spread of coronavirus.He said: The only way to think about this is a war, where we look at what the entire resources of the nation are and how we can best deploy those to save lives.Weve got to think about how we bring all the resources of the country to get through this.He added that everything possible was being done to avoid a peak in cases as Boris Johnson last night said he was absolutely confident the country could send coronavirus packing in  weeks.Boris added British experts expect to start trials for a vaccine against Covid- within a month, although expectations are that a vaccine will take at least a year.It comes as the Queen issued a rallying cry telling Brits to pull their weight in the fight against COVID- and avoid the pub and panic buying.She said: I am certain we are up to the challenge.Our history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one.The Monarch is currently self-isolating in Windsor Castle having cancelled public events in Cheshire and Camden.Her message to protect the most vulnerable comes as supermarkets were put under immense strain amid panic-buying Brits.Yesterday, key workers who will play a role in fighting coronavirus were named including nurses, police officers and delivery drivers. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus covid 19 super rich testing kit private jets leo mckinstry
story: JUMPING the queue, expensive testing kits and escaping to distant sanctuaries in private jets - this isnt just isolation, this is elite, super-rich isolation.As the coronavirus pandemic sweeps across the world, some celebrities, millionaires, and members of the business class seem to believe that their wealth can be used as a form of vaccination while the rest of us face the deadly risk of infection.Such behaviour is entirely against the public spirit of the moment. This is a time for unity and for respecting others, especially the most vulnerable.As the Queen put it yesterday in her admirable statement: “I am reminded that our nation’s history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal.”As the emergency deepens, abuse of privilege should play no part in our national response.But that is exactly what is now happening, as is graphically demonstrated by the saga of private Covid- tests kits.One of the biggest problems the Government faces is the shortage of capacity for testing.To prevent the current system from being overwhelmed by demand, NHS policy is only to test people with a “high chance” of having the illness, such as those who have ed from high-risk countries or are displaying symptoms.Even doctors and nurses working in the front-line are not routinely tested.But to evade such official restrictions, a growing number of the rich and famous are forking out for private coronavirus kits, which can cost anything between £ and £.According to one report this week, more than , wealthy figures in Britain have ordered such kits.Dr Mark Ali, director of the Harley Street clinic, said: “We have private iniduals – some recognisable names there – and we are testing lords and ladies and even doctors and dentists who are worried about catching the disease.”It is the same story of privileged access in the US, where, just as in Britain, shortages of supplies mean that many health care workers and sick people are unable to get diagnoses.But some stars seek to bypass rules that limit tests to those most at risk.A huge controversy erupted this week at the news that eight top NBA basketball teams has been tested, making a mockery of the rationing.Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York, spoke for much of the public when he said that “an entire NBA team should not get tested for Covid- while there are critically ill patients waiting to be tested. Tests should not be for the wealth, but for the sick.”On both sides of the Atlantic, this two-tiered approach is wrong on so many levels.It is a deep insult to healthcare workers. It is profoundly isive.And it does not lessen the burdens on the NHS here in Britain, as some apologists pretend.Those who test positive will still have to be treated in the health service, since the British private medical sector does not have the resources for this crisis.Selfish and irresponsible, the Covid-test queue jumpers are the equivalents of the supermarket stockpilers or the social distancing refuseniks who still insist on going down to the pub.During the Second World War, when the Blitz spirit was at its peak, there was fierce hostility to rich iniduals who tried to cheat on rationing regulations or avoid national service.The same contempt should now be shown to those who try to dodge the rules that promote fairness.But it is not just in testing where the narrow self-centredness of the rich can be found. They use their wealth to insulate themselves in other ways.Some are buying special private medical care, like intravenous infusions of vitamins and minerals to boost their immune system.Lansherhof, a private medical facility at the London Arts Club, reported this week an  per cent increase in enquires for its Immune Plus Support Infusion, which costs £.The rich are also using private jet travel to avoid the rest of the public as they conduct business or fly to remote havens.Inquiries for international flights by private jets are estimated to be up nine-fold since the outbreak began, while Hong Kong International Airport reported this week its busiest day for private jet activity.Nor do the rich have to endure the normal airport ordeal suffered by other passengers.A spokeswoman for Quintessentially, a concierge company for millionaires, said: “Members who are travelling commercially are choosing to book elite services at airports, not your typical first-class lounge.For example, private terminals where guests are greeted and given their own suite.Check-in, customs and security are all done privately and guests are taken to the doors of the aircraft.Members can request for the jetty to be cleared so they minimise the interactions with other passengers”.Most Brits have no choice over where they live in the midst of this crisis.But that is not true of the wealthy who can find sanctuary in one of their many properties or rent out an expensive rural bolt-hole.Some are now paying £,-a-month for a luxury base in the Cotswolds.Nor does self-isolation have to be the imprisoning experience that it is for ordinary citizens.The rich can bring in private chefs for their dinners, or expensive tutors for their children.The company Tutors International, which provides elite tuition services, says it has seen “a massive upswing in requests” since the outbreak began.The elite even have luxury face masks. The fashionable Airinum Urban Air Mask costs £ and claims to protect “against airborne particles as small as .mm.”But in this rarefied world, problems are faced by the elite that would never be considered by others.Wailing that she now has now chance to show off her expensive jewellery, one female financier in London says: “I’m just not sure when my next ball will be.”The experience of the affluent is in dramatic contrast to the misery faced by people at the other end of the scale.While the rich cocoon themselves, it is the wage-earners, the straitened households, the poor and the unemployed who are now in the eye of the storm.Our society is just beginning to realize the terrying consequences of this disaster, where the mounting death toll is matched by economic meltdown.Vast numbers of people – from hotel cleaners to airline cabin crew, from bar staff to retail assistants – are going to lose their jobs.The ranks of the five million self-employed will be decimated. Small businesses across the country will collapse.Food banks are already running short of supplies, while the plight of the homeless – who cannot isolate themselves on the streets – is desperate as shelters close.At worst, our prosperous civilisation could slide into a kind of modern feudal structure, with only the aristocracy at the top enjoying a decent standard of living.At a press conference in the White House on Wednesday, President Trump was asked whether “the well-connected go to the front of the line”.He replied philosophically: “You’d have to ask them that. Perhaps that’s been the story of le.”But it should not be that way, especially when mankind is facing one of its darkest hours.We should all be in this together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sainsburys staff barricade isle toilet roll
story: SUPERMARKET staff had to barricade an entire aisle from shoppers so they could restock toilet roll without being overrun by frantic panic-buyers.The aisle for cleaning products and toilet paper at Grimsbys Sainsburys store had to be closed off to shoppers to give staff the chance to restock the shelves.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesBut after putting out two and a half stock trolleys of toilet paper out they removed the metal barricades, with the aisle quickly flooding with customers to grab them.Toilet paper is currently limited to two per person in Sainsburys, but that did not stop customers grabbing the large multi-packs while they could.One bemused shopper said: Its all a bit mad really — they shouldnt have to do this for toilet roll.I cant believe its got as bad as this — I only needed one pack because I was running out.Another shopper fumed: Ive tried to find loo roll all over and its always been sold out.Thankfully Ive timed it right and managed to get here for when theyre putting stock out.Supermarkets across North East Lincolnshire have been struggling to handle the demand of panic buying due to the coronavirus.Grimsbys Asda store had to put a security guard on the door due to over  customers queuing outside waiting for the doors to open at am.They were forced to keep one door closed while security asked shoppers to travel at a safe speed coming into the store.Large queues had already started outside the store at .am, with the car park virtually full by .am.I only want to buy butter and milk for my elderly mum as she was running low, exclaimed another shopper.Its ridiculous that the supermarkets arent doing more to allow us to shop for relatives that cant get out and shop.At Iceland on Bethlehem Street there were similar scenes, with a queue of more than  people at am before opening.One shopper at Iceland said: I didnt live through the Second World War, but I bet it was never like this.While, over at Tesco Extra in Cleethorpes, the shelves were stripped bare by customers, with one worker saying that both of their deliveries that day had sold out.Fresh food, meat, bread, eggs and canned food were all cleared in just a few hours on Thursday morning as people filled trolleys due to the coronavirus outbreak.One shopper said: The staff arent even restocking the shelves at the moment, so anyone finishing work later today will be coming in to an empty shop.Stores up and down the country have reduced the amount of products that people can buy, as well as offering priority delivery slots and special opening hours for its elderly customers.Supermarket delivery drivers have also been named as key workers by the government as they announced full school closures across the UK.This will mean that,they have children, they will still have to go to school to ensure that their parents can work. Currently, there are no confirmed cases of the disease in North East Lincolnshire at the moment, but those with symptoms have been advised to self-isolate, rather than visit a hospital to get tested.Despite this, government advice is for people to follow social distancing, which aims to reduce the amount of close contact people have with one another.This includes avoiding venues such as pubs, clubs, restaurants, cinemas, and theatres, and to work from home whenever possible.To receive our
