title: coronavirus key worker jobs list confusing
story: THE government’s list of key workers who are vital to help fight the coronavirus crisis is confusing parents who say: “Every man and his dog is covered.”This morning, Boris Johnson named the key workers whose children will be allowed back to school as they play a crucial role in Britains battle against the bug.It comes as:But this has led to widespread confusion over who qualies as a key worker because the definitions are so vague and many are asking their bosses for guidance.Thousands of kids today arrived at school for their last day after the deadly coronavirus outbreak forced an abrupt end to their lessons.However, it is believed that a considerable number of schools will have to open on Monday for children whose parent is a “key worker”.The government announced that the jobs - which include nurses, police officers and delivery drivers - are key to their war on the deadly bug, which has killed  people and infected , people in the UK.Click here to see the full list of workers.Confused parents slammed the list today and asked: “What was the point of shutting schools ”A junior school headteacher from Nottinghamshire said today: “Pretty much every single job is covered, we may as well just stay open.”One parent added: “So the government have shut schools and said only kids of key workers can attend from Monday.“They then issue a list of key workers that pretty much includes every man and his dog.“What the hell was the point of shutting schools ”A Year  teacher, from North London, said: “Well it looks like back to normal teaching on Mondaythe list of key workers is anything to go by.”Another confused parent added: “The government has caused total chaos in schools. Too many questions unanswered.”The working heroes include court staff, religious staff, supermarket workers and some financial workers. Their children will be exempt from the decision to close classrooms from Monday to stop the spread of the deadly bug.A No source confirmed to The Sun Online only one parent needs to be eligible for kids to be allowed back to class.The Government today named nine sectors “critical to the COVID- response” – Health and social care Education and childcare Key public services Local and national government Food and necessary goods Public safety and national security Transport and Utilities, communication and financial services.Families have been urged not to leave their children with grandparents aged over  in order to protect the elderly, who are most at risk from the deadly bug.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: “We still need to have our critical infrastructure that continues to work and .”The announcement as Boris Johnson spells out his warplan to beat coronavirus.Yesterday, Britain’s death toll rose to  with a total of , confirmed cases.Boris told the nation he is “absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country” and the tide can be turned within three months.He said: “I’m conscious as the days have gone by that people will want to know how long we’re expecting them to keep it up.“I think, looking at it all, that we can turn the tide within the next  weeks and I’m absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country.“But onlywe all take the steps that we’ve outlined, that is vital, that’s how we’re going to reduce the peak and once we’ve achieved that and I think that we will,we take the steps I’ve said, then the scientic progress that we’ve been making will really start coming into play.”Boris added British experts expect to start trials for a vaccine against Covid- within a month, although expectations are that a vaccine will take at least a year.He said: To give you an idea of what is coming down the track, were in negotiations today to buy a so-called antibody test, as simple as a pregnancy test, which can tell whether you have had the disease and its early days, butit works as its proponents claim, then we will buy literally hundreds of thousands of these kits as soon as practicable.It comes as the Queen issued a rallying cry telling Brits to pull their weight in the fight against COVID- and avoid the pub and panic buying.She said: I am certain we are up to the challenge.Our history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one.The Monarch is currently self-isolating in Windsor Castle having cancelled public events in Cheshire and Camden.Her message to protect the most vulnerable comes as supermarkets were put under immense strain amid panic-buying Brits.Shoppers have been pictured brawling over toilet paper and booze after fears the UK could be put under lockdown. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social distancing must be in place year coronavirus
story: SOCIAL distancing may need to be in place for most of a year to tackle coronavirus, according to the countrys top experts.The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies , which is advising the government on its response to the pandemic, has today published a report on its evidence. The team of scientists have insisted social distancing measures will need to be in place for at least most of a year to stop intensive care units being overwhelmed.It comes after Boris Johnson said last night that the UK could turn the tide against the illness in  weeks - as the number of deaths in the UK soared to  today.The newly-published advice from SAGE, which was agreed on Monday, says that the severity of social distancing measures could alternate during the periodHowever, the experts say that stricter measures  would need to be in place for at least half of the year in order to keep cases at a level the NHS can cope with.Strict measures could include school closures and social distancing for everyone, while less restrictive measures include isolating cases and households.The report states: It was agreed that the addition of both general social distancing and school closures - to case isolation, household isolation and social distancing of vulnerable groups - would be likely to control the epidemic when kept in place for a long period.It was agreed that a policy of alternating between periods of more and less strict social distancing measures could plausibly be effective at keeping the number of critical care cases within capacity.These would need to be in place for at least most of a year.Under such as policy, at least half of the year would be spent under the stricter social distancing measures.The document says that the triggers for measures to be put in place or lted could y according to dferent regions.There would be a two to three-week delay between measures being put into place and their impact being felt in intensive care units, it added.Government chief scientic adviser, Sir Patrick Vallance, said: This is an incredibly fast-moving developing situation and as part of our collective efforts to give the clearest and most reliable scientic advice, SAGE has and continues to draw upon a huge range of experts and a huge range of evidence.The UK is home to experts who are at the forefront of their chosen fields and we are making full use of their expertise to grow our understanding of Covid- as we work tirelessly to tackle this disease.The collective evidence we have published today has played a considerable role in shaping our recommendations on when, how and why the government have made the interventions it has so far.On Thursday, the Prime Minister said the tide on Covid- could be turned in the next  weeks but added he could not promise that the UK would definitely be on a downward slope from the peak of the virus.He said: I cannot stand here and tell you that by the end of June we will be on the downward slope.Its possible but I simply cant say that for certain. Of course not, we dont know where we are, we dont know how long this thing will go on for but what I can say is that this is going to be finite, we will turn the tide and I can see how to do it within the next  weeks.It comes as:It comes as Health Secretary Matt Hancock said people undergoing treatment for cancer and others who form part of a group of around . million people will receive specic advice on what to do to keep themselves safe from coronavirus.At present, anyone with an underlying health condition such as those who usually receive an NHS flu jab, people with weakened immune systems and anyone over  is told to be particularly stringent in following social distancing measures.But those who are at even higher risk of severe illness from Covid-, including recipients of donor organs, those on active chemotherapy or radiotherapy, people with blood cancers and those with severe chest conditions will be given more tailored advice.Mr Hancock told Sky News: The first thing were going to do is set out exactly what conditions that applies to.We expect about . million people to then get a communication from the NHS to say that they are part of this and what they need to do.Many of these people have pre-existing health conditions and so will be very worried right now, and I understand that, and theyll need very specic sets of action. For instance, how do you go about still getting your chemoyou have cancer whilst also social-distancing If you have cancer its particularly important to stay away from other people, but you also of course have got to keep going with your chemotherapy.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Mr Hancock added: These are some of the most dficult and challenging cases so well be getting in contact with them, butpeople think that they are on this list and dont receive a communication from the NHS, then they also need to get in contact.So that is under way, the money was announced for it yesterday. A combination of money to the NHS and money to councils because theyve got a very big part to play in keeping people safe.It comes as an army of , retired nurses and doctors have been told “Your NHS Needs You” in the battle against coronavirus.Medical students and trainee nurses are also being invited to join the fight — while members of the public have been askedthey can help, too.The Prime Minister said he expects the tide to be turned in the fight within  weeks, as he urged the public to follow social distancing advice and for businesses to stand by your employees.But he implied that this is onlythe public heeds the social distancing guidance, saying: I know its tough, I know its dficult... but please, please follow the advice.But pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars in recent days. The PM also said British experts expect to start trials for a vaccine against the virus within a month, although expectations are that a vaccine will take at least a year.Mr Johnson added that a game-changer antibody test was coming down the track which could identy whether somebody somebody had become immune to the disease so they couldto their daily le.He has pledged to massively increase testing to up to , a day, which combined with collective action and scientic progress he said would save many, many thousands of lives.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family decking tear down south wales
story: Jamie Davies put up the large decking to give his family privacy in their South Wales garden.But when the -year-old applied for back-dated retrospective planning permission he was refused, and has to rip it out.Council planners slammed the £, decking as the most appalling thing as they kicked out his application to keep the superdeck at his £, home.Now the Davies family face legal action unless they rip out the decking - unless they can find a compromise with planners.A council planning committee heard no neighbours had objected to the garden frame in the development in Blaina.But councillor Bernard Willis raged: “If that was being built near my house I would be appalled.“I think it is a dreadful thing to be looking at and in my view we should not be approving this application.”The family wanted to add plants to hide the steel from view, but the application to keep it was thrown out by eight votes to seven.Dad Jamie, manager of a sports centre, said: We put the decking up to give privacy for the children while they play.The next step for us will be talking to the planning officers and seeing what we can do next. We dont know about an appeal yet.Councillor Lisa Winnett told Blaenau Gwent planners that she was in favour of the build.She said: “Many developments are quite similar.“I do not see an issue with the visual impact of thisplanting is done on the outside.”Garden decking became all the rage from the late s - with makeover show Ground Force getting the blame for the boom.Retailer BQ reported an increase in sales of the lawn alternative from £, in  to a staggering £million in .Presenter Alan Titchmarsh accepted the blame for the lawn cover-up - saying at the time: I am sorry, I know its everywhere these days.Last year we told of epic design fails are so bad that youll struggle to believe they actually happened in the real world.From a meaty marble dining set to hilarious advert blunders, we reveal the top picks of the worst creations designers contributed to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog breeders joy after callie the bulldog gives birth to twenty puppies
story: Callie the bulldog was in labour for an exhausting three days as she gave birth to her huge litter.Breeder Amber Rees and her partner were thrilled at all the puppies and are doing their best to cope with all the new additions to their household.Amber, from Swindon, Wilts, have only just set up her new business, Blue Blood Empire for a particularly rare breeds of dogs - Alapaha blue blood bulldogs.While nine of Callies remarkable litter did not survive past their first week, the other eleven are thriving and are a great start for Amber and her business.She admitted looking after them was proving dficult.She told Wessex news: This could be a record litter for Swindon and they can be quite a handful.I think Callies handled this better than I have. Its been chaotic and crazy but quite fun.Amber said the adorable additions were heartwarming to have around.She said: Seeing all those puppies together has been really heartwarming and sweet but it does test your patience sometimes.We are so proud of Callie, shes done so well, all things considered.This was her first litter and it was tough to see her go through so much effort but shes been such a good mother.After a good rest, Callie is back on her feet and enjoying her huge litter of puppies.Amber said: She was very tired for a few days but shes started wagging her tail again and is back to her funny, ditzy old self.At first we were a bit nervous because we were not sure how well she would look after the puppies but she responds whenever one of them makes a noise and is always on her guard immediatelyanyone comes near them.The puppies came as a huge surprise to Amber, who wasnt expecting anywhere near the amount of puppies to be born.When we first took her for a scan, the vet told us to expect six or at most eight puppies, but they just kept on coming. I was shocked but delighted.After the first , she slowed down a bit so the vet gave her an injection to help give her contractions and push the last six out.The nine that did not make it were born too prematurely and did not survive more than a few days.Amber added: It was a bit of a traumatic birth and Callies waters broke before some of them were ready to come out.The others are happy and healthy, fortunately, and weve stocked up on beds and dog food for them.Now we just need to think of  names to officially register each puppy.I thought about going with Disney princesses for the females but after calling one of them Ariel, I decided that it didnt really suit her.When a new owner buys them, they can rename them. Callie was originally called Gabana.

title: pubs london closed coronavirus
story: PUBS, restaurants, and other venues in London will be ordered to close over the coronavirus surge.Boris Johnson chaired an emergency meeting this morning as the Government tries to find ways to battle the outbreak.Gyms, leisure centres and cinemas all across the capital are facing closures, with Boris expected to make the announcement at todays pm press conference.Shops are not expected to be affected in the move, but could be struck down laterthe outbreak fails to slow down.It comes amid growing concerns that Brits are refusing to social distance, and continuing to pile into pubs and clubs after work.Pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars as they continue to ignore government advice.The pub-goers have been slammed on social media after cases of the killer bug rose to , yesterday with  deaths in the UK.The Government earlier insisted that London would not be going on lockdown, and there were no plans to stop people leaving their homes.They also stressed that Brits will also not be confined to their homes as the UK death toll hit .It comes as:Matt Hancock had earlier pleaded with the public to follow Government advice, insisting it was the only way to get it dealt with in -weeks.He explained: “If people follow the advice, we can get through this quicker.“Evenyou dont think you are personally at risk because you are younger, which by the way isnt true, this affects everybody,you dont follow the advice we are going to have to keep these measures in place for longer.“For everyones sake I think everyone needs to pull together and listen to the experts.”Sadiq Khan has told Londoners to “stop travelling and avoid social interaction”.He said:  “People should not be travelling, by any means, unless they really, really have to.“Londoners should be avoiding social interaction unless absolutely necessary, and that means they should be avoiding using the transport network unless absolutely necessary.”Wetherspoons owner Tim Martin had earlier insisted his pubs would be open for the duration.Despite the pandemic, he said: I think that once you shut them down its very dficult.Supermarkets are very, very crowded. Pubs are much less crowded. Theres hardly been any transmission of the virus within pubs and I think its over the top to shut them.Thats a commercial view but also a common sense view.Piers Morgan hit back at his comments, labelling them insane stupidity.

title: brit in barcelona coronavirus lockdown shares supermarket pics
story: When lockdown was announced on Friday Victoria Mullen said the supermarket shelves were bare.People were struggling to get hold of essential items like pasta and toilet rolls but now they are realising there is no need to stockpile.“Seeing so much negativity and fear I wanted to try to share something to help the worry of going on lockdown,” Victoria told Birmingham Live.“We are on lockdown in Barcelona ... however, we are allowed out to the supermarket and to the pharmacy and, contrary to belief, you’re not holed up for the whole time, you can go out for essentials as long as you are straight back home.”“You’re allowed out to walk your dogs etc, just no social gathering at all. What you’re seeing on social media is causing fear and panic and making you bulk buy which is affecting the vulnerable and the supermarkets cannot keep up with the demand.“I took some photos today in the supermarket in a country that is on lockdown to show you what it looks like, you will not be without food.“Just to confirm on Friday when lockdown was announced our shelves were bare and we had no pasta or toilet roll just like you’re seeing.”Victoria, who is from Middlesbrough, added: This is five days in and we are stabilising as people have realised there is no need to bulk buy. Hoping this helps and you see the same.“Please try not to worry and try to give the shops a chance to catch up with the demand and give others a chance to get what they need.“Keep calm, carry on and be safe.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gridlock as hundreds rush to cross from mexico into us as border is set to close today
story: HUNDREDS of Americans rushed to cross into the U.S. from Mexico, as the border is set to close today amid the coronavirus pandemic.The border will remain open mainly for trade and will restrict travel, as officials work to limit international travel amid the COVID- outbreak.Pictures show cars lined up in a gridlock as the border was expected to close Friday for an undisclosed amount of time.In bumper-to-bumper lines, people made a rush for the border as they tried to cross before travel to and from Mexico is shut Friday.The rush came as more than , cases of COVID- have been confirmed in the U.S., with at least  deaths.Much like travel bans already in place for Europe and Canada, the ban was set to halt nonessential travel and just allow for trade across the countries.Essential workers – including farmworkers, grocery store employees, and restaurant and grocery store employees will be allowed to cross from the U.S. and Mexico for their jobs, according to a list given by U.S. officials, but the border will be closed for most travel, Paola Avila, chair of the Border Trade Alliance said.Mexican Foreign Relations Secretary Marcelo Ebrard said he proposed steps that wont paralyze economic activity and keep the border open to commerce with work, when speaking with U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo on Thursday.Mexico is Americas largest trading partner, with the U.S. accounting for  percent of the countrys exports.The expected border closure comes just after the U.S. Department of State issued a Global Level  Health Advisory, warning Americans to avoid all international travel.Calornias Governor Gavin Newsom ordered all residents to stay home unless they need to leave for absolutely necessary things, like grocery shopping or dog walking on Thursday.Any U.S. citizens living abroad that need tohome have been urged to do so immediately, unless they expect to remain abroad indefinitely.Pompeo said he and Ebrard have been working closely on travel restrictions that balance protecting our citizens from further transmission of #COVID on Twitter Thursday evening.Together, we can reduce public health risks and prioritize essential cross-border commerce and trade, Pompeo said.Officials had not made an official announcement on the details of the border close, but they are expected to come Friday.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus bins no collections
story: FAMILIES have today been told to take their rubbish to the tip as bin collections will be cancelled during the coronavirus outbreak.Councils across the country have scaled back household bin collections and people have been told take their own waste to the dump rather than wait for lorries.It comes as:On Thursday, Cambridge City Council announced it would suspend all garden waste collections from Monday until May .The council said on its website: The suspension of green bin collections will allow crews to concentrate on emptying blue and black bins during the coming weeks.It will also assist with any future staff sickness or self-isolation issues.Some local councils have suspended waste collection services in a bid to stop the spread of Covid-, which has killed  people and infected , people in the UK.Other councils are also following suit, including Cheshire West and Chester, and Derby City Council, the latter of which has also suspended bulky waste collections.GO TO THE TIPDerby City Council said it predicts the coronavirus pandemic will also affect recycling and general waste collections in the coming weeks.Local authorities are asking residents who are self-isolating to place personal waste - such as used tissues and cleaning materials - into a plastic bag before disposing of it into a second bin bag.They are then encouraged to store it safely in their homes for  hours before placing it into a wheelie bin for collection.Hackney Council said this measure aimed to lower the risk of the virus being passed on.Meanwhile, Brighton and Hove Council is urging people with cars to take the rubbish of friends and neighbours who are unable to do so.The move has infuriated residents - especially the elderly - who have no means of disposing of rubbish.Eileen French, , said: “What are the elderly supposed to do “We have bins overflowing into the streets and no way of getting rid of it. I think it is disgraceful the council has made this announcement so soon into this crisis.“Coronavirus raises all sorts of public health concerns and the council seems to be abdicating responsibility.”Ellie Wood, from Brighton, said: “At times of stress it is up to the council to try and maintain basic services. Rubbish strewn across streets is a clear sign of civil breakdown.“The council has a responsibility to maintain collections not just from a health and hygiene position but also to reassure residents that there won’t be some total deterioration of services.”Another resident said: “This the exact moment they should be going the extra mile, for all of us, including themselves. If refuse starts piling up in the streets, other diseases will spread, put extra strain on the NHS.“The bin collectors will not escape these consequences either.”A spokesman for Brighton and Hove Council said: “We will be unable to catch up on missed work. If a collection is missed, residents’ next collection will take place on their next scheduled collection daypossible.“Residents can take any type of waste to the two Household Waste Recycling Centres . This can include taking friends and neighbours wastethey can’t get there by car.”A spokesman for the Local Government Association said: As councils prioritise protecting the vulnerable, there will be inevitable disruption to other important services, such as bin collections and street cleaning.Some councils are having to change their waste and recycling services as coronavirus impacts on their collection staff.Residents are encouraged to visit their council website for ongoing updates on bin collections.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus doctor photography competition scottish mountains
story: Dr Kenny Muir won the prestigious title with his stunning pictures taken in remote parts of Scotland.Dr Muir was labelled Scottish Photographer for the Year with his breathtaking photos.The stand-out picture was of Seilebost Gneiss, where he captured the Luskentyre estuary, framed by the snowy mountains of North Harris.He said: “I am shocked and delighted to have won this competition, particularly when surrounded by so many talented photographers.“Two of the winning images are part of a personal project to document the wilder side of Glen Affric, one of Scotland’s largest remnants of Caledonian Forest. I hope to highlight the importance of preserving and regenerating these areas of natural beauty.”His win comes as the confirmed cases of coronavirus continued to soar to , in the UK with  deaths.Dr Muirs portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Dr Muir is currently fighting the outbreak of the deadly COVID- virus at Raigmore hospital in Inverness, Scotland.He said he would need to take a break from photography to focus all his efforts on keeping people alive and well.As a hospital doctor I will be taking a break from photography to focus on current events, but really appreciate receiving the award.His portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Another standout shot was of one of the many small lochs deep within Glen Affric, capturing morning lighting hitting the native pinewoods after an evening of snow.The Scottish Landscape Photographer of the Year competition consists of a number of categories, including Landscape, Seascape, Urban, Monochrome, Four Seasons and Scottish Weather.Andrew Bulloch, from Edinburgh, won the Youth Category for the second year running, with his image of ‘The “Beast from the East” hits Edinburgh’.Andrew said: “The heavy snowstorms that hit the UK in March  were clearly visible as they swept across the city. I climbed to the summit of Arthur’s Seat to get the best viewpoint and had to get pulled out of a snowdrt on my way down.”Founder of the competition Stuart Low said in this tough times, he hoped the photos would give everyone some much needed joy.Stuart said: “In these dficult times ahead of us, we hope these stunning images will bring a little joy to everyone.”All the winning images will be showcased in a limited edition book that will be available from April .

title: seagulls in benidorm lockdown
story: A RAVENOUS colony of seagulls praying on an elderly shopper in coronavirus-stricken Spain have been captured on camera.In the attack, which looks like it’s been taken from the script of Alfred Hitchcock’s Hitchcock’s horror classic, The Birds, the gulls can be seen tormenting the elderly person who is carrying their shopping in Benidorm.Locals claimed online the aggressive birds have now taken to attacking people on brief trips for groceries in the ghost town resort.Their normal source of food is said to have vanished after bars and restaurants were shut and everyone was ordered to stay inside on Monday.Spain has become the fourth-hardest hit country in the world, after China, Italy which has now become the epicentre of the outbreak, and Iran.A total of , people have died in Spain after testing positive for coronavirus.British tourists holidaying in the country were this week urged to ‘leave now’, after the government said hotels would be on shutdown from next week.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Over the weekend Brits were spotted defying the country’s lockdown and taunting police in Benidorm at the weekend.A video which appeared on social media showed a group of around  people — some topless, others holding cans of beer —  boisterously chanting outside a block of flats as officers attempt to get them to go inside.Comments underneath the video state get them back to the UK and what unconsciousness, irresponsibility and stupidity.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: vat suspended for three months
story: The Chancellor has relieved the pressure on firms by deferring the next quarter of VAT payments, worth more than £ billion.A loan scheme to help cash-starved firms will also be  extended to help companies through the economic storm.The governments intervention comes as the the UKs COVID- death toll hit .Appealing to the British people to pull together, Mr Sunak vowed to stand behind the UKs workforce and its employers as he unveiled the Coronavirus Job Retention Scheme.The VAT holiday will give firms valuable breathing space as they fight to stay afloat during the epidemic, which has ripped across the world.Mr Sunak said: To help businesses keep people in work, Im deferring the next quarter of VAT payments.That means no business will pay VAT from now to mid June. Youll have until the end of the financial year to repay those bills.Thats a direct injection of over £bn of cash to businesses equivalent to . per cent of GDP.A loan scheme to help businesses will also now be interest free for a year, up from six months.The Coronavirus Business Interruption Loan Scheme will be available from Monday.Mr Sunak assured businesses we in government are doing everything we can to protect you as he rolled out  the Treasurys battle plan.He added: We want to look back on this time and remember how in the face of a generation-defining moment, we undertook a collective national effort and we stood together.Its on all of us.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.The government will also cover up to  per cent of workers wages up to £, a month through grant funding - worth as much as £, a year per employee.It would cover earnings backdated to March  and be open for at least three months with no limit on the amount of funding available.Mr Sunak described the bumper package he unveiled today as unprecedented in the history of the British state.In support of businesses and workers Mr Sunak wrote a blank cheque by also announcing:The Government is also pledging nearly £ billion for renters through increasing housing benefit and Universal Credit.Todays announcement comes on the back of a £ billion coronavirus loan scheme for businesses to access, which was announced by Mr Sunak on Tuesday.Business chiefs have given the Chancellors new measures a massive thumbs up today.Adam Marshall, director general of the British Chambers of Commerce, said: The chancellor has given businesses desperately needed breathing room at this critical moment.The deferral of VAT payments keeps money in the pockets of businesses so that they can pay their people and suppliers, and the commitment to cover wages of those unable to work will allow firms to retain jobsthey are forced to reduce their operations.The Prime Minister also revealed that pubs restaurants and leisure centres across the whole of Britain will shut as soon as possible tonight amid the spiralling coronavirus crisis.Speaking alongside Mr Sunak, Boris Johnson made the unprecedented announcement ordering all venues to shut their doors as the government tries to battle the outbreak. Pubs restaurants and leisure centres across the whole of Britain will shut as soon as possible tonight amid the spiralling coronavirus crisis.Speaking alongside Mr Sunak, Boris Johnson made the unprecedented announcement this evening ordering all venues to shut their doors as the Government tries to battle the outbreak.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.

title: parents key workers children remain school
story: THE Government has officially closed all schools until the summer, expect for children of key workers.But who counts as a key workers and what are the requirements for children to head in to school during the pandemic  Here is what is expected to happen.Key workers are people in roles that play a crucial part in Britains fight against coronavirus.The Government has named these roles which includes nurses, police officers and delivery drivers.As a result, their children will be allowed back to school from Monday, while the rest of the nations students will be exempt from entering the classroom.Full government guidelines here.This is how the government defines the groups of key workers:This includes but is not limited to doctors, nurses, midwives, paramedics, social workers, care workers, and other frontline health and social care staff including volunteers.This includes nursery and teaching staff, social workers and those specialist education professionals who must remain active during the COVID- response to deliver this approach.This includes those essential to the running of the justice system, religious staff, charities and workers delivering key frontline services, those responsible for the management of the deceased, and journalists and broadcasters who are providing public service broadcasting.This only includes those administrative occupations essential to the effective delivery of the COVID- response or delivering essential public services such as the payment of benefits, including in government agencies and armsbodies.This includes those involved in food production, processing, distribution, sale and delivery as well as those essential to the provision of other key goods .This includes police and support staff, Ministry of Defence civilians, contractor and armed forces personnel , fire and rescue service employees and more.This includes those who will keep the air, water, road and rail passenger and freight transport modes operating during the COVID- response, including those working on transport systems through which supply chains pass.This includes staff needed for essential financial services provision , the oil, gas, electricity and water sectors , information technology, data infrastructure sector and more.No - they do not. Children with at least one parent who is classied as a key worker will be allowed to remain in school.A skeleton network of schools and nurseries will remain open for the children of key workers where they will be supervised during the day.But they will not be taught the national curriculum due to the fact all exams in May and June have been cancelled.It is the first time the school examinations have not gone ahead since the system was put in place in .In a live broadcast, Prime Minister Boris Johnson  announced that schools across the whole of the UK will be closed after todayas Britain tries to contain the coronavirus outbreak.Secretary of State for Education Gavin Williamson promised that free school meals will continue for everyone who needs it - likely in the form of supermarket vouchers.Boris told the nation on Thursday evening that the spread was slowing as a result of the draconian measures he put in place this week.The PM explained: We believe the steps we have already taken, together with those I am announcing today, are already slowing the spread of the disease.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: NewsopinionMy coronavirus isolation diary - I woke up feeling like Id smoked  cigarettes in an hourThe Mirrors political correspondent Mikey Smith describes his experience of self-isolation with suspected coronavirus - saying taking one step feels like too muchShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  MAR NewsopinionMirrors political correspondent Mikey Smith is self-isolating at home with suspected coronavirus" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailItaposs Wednesday. The last couple of days I’ve woken up feeling like I’d smoked  cigarettes the night before. Yesterday I woke up feeling like I’d smoked  in the last hour. I had an occasional - but not continuous - cough, a headache and aches in my muscles. It was time to self-isolate. I’d already been working from home since Sunday and hadn’t really been out and about much since Friday. Our team started ‘social distancing’ at the end of last week, cutting down the number of staff physically in our office in the Houses of Parliament to the minimum to avoid unnecessary spreading. I’ve worked from home before, so I like to think I know a lot of the tricks. Get dressed. Don’t work in bed - have a desk set up, evenit’s the kitchen table. Have a set beginning and end to your work day. But I didn’t make it past step one yesterday. My partner is - so far - asymptomatic, but has entered isolation with me. We share an extremely small home - welcome to London - so she’s inevitably a couple of days behind me.  Both of us have made a point of not stockpiling. We’ve got enough - ahem - personal items to last a couple of weeks, but that’s about what we keep in anyway. The only things we’ve got more of than usual are ‘quality of le’ things, like a couple of bags of nice coffee beans. Little luxuries that make a couple of weeks stuck in the house feel less like a prison sentence.  Of course, in trying to do the right thing, we’ve ended up without a few things. Nothing dramatic - the biggest problem is that I don’t have a thermometer in the house, so I can’t tellI actually have a temperature. Not sure it matters at this point - my chest feeling like it’s being crushed under a rock is enough evidence for me - but it would have been nice. But a big shout out to the guys on Amazon offering £. thermometers for free delivery in a month’s time - or £you want it this week. Classy. Anyway, I’m settled in. I’m drinking lots of fluids, resting in bed and getting used to the four walls I’ll be looking at for the next week. Symptoms: Coughing, shortness of breath and chest tightness, headache, muscle pains. What’s entertaining me: Season  of Star Trek: Deep Space Nine on Netflix. Fire Emblem: Three Houses on the Nintendo Switch Thursday

title: coronavirus postponed wedding worry wont
story: NewsopinionCoronavirus has postponed our wedding - and I worry I wont live until new dateMum, author and Mirror columnist Roisin Pelan will need chemotherapy for the rest of her le to treat her incurable cancer, but Covid means she wont be getting married this summerShareCommentsByRoisin Pelan:,  MAR NewsopinionMy sisters upset at the wedding being cancelled really brought it home to me " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe biggest, absolutely worst news I have this week is that our wedding has been postponed. It’s due in July and with so many family members coming from around the world, it’s unlikely that it will be able to go ahead. It’s been such a massive decision but last night, I had a voicemail from my sister who lives in Melbourne and who has battled breast cancer alongside me since my recurrence. . She was absolutely devastated on the phone and it broke my heart into a trillion pieces. She has always been pretty pragmatic and solid as as rock and she has always bloody mothered me. so to hear her sobs was just awful. Our wedding for her is massive and we just can’t do it without her. Our beautul venue, Hobbit Hill, is looking at rescheduling all weddings and so we asked about the possibility of changing our date until July  but all summer dates are booked up. Nooooooooo! We’d really wanted to get married in the summer as the venue has so many gorgeous outdoorsy treats. We were going to be married in the outdoor woodland. Buuuut what can we do  We have changed it to th April and all we can do is hope for some lovely April spring. The devil on my shoulder was there straight away telling me I won’t even be alive to see . Ugh, cancer I hate youI don’t know about anyone , but this has really triggered my cancer anxiety again. Homeschooling Ivy and having her so close to me all the time - it makes me frightened that something bad will happen and she’ll have to be without me. She just couldn’t cope. So many emotions at the moment, stress, worry, fear, anxiety, hope, anger, love. Allll the feels. But anyway, wow - absolute meltdown across the globe. We’re witnessing something we’ve never seen in our letime - toilet roll hoarders, greedy capitalist pigs. It’s bringing out the worst in a lot of us. My brother is stuck in Spain - Ryanair have offered to fly him home for an additional £. My friends ran out of her £. baby formula, but it’s okay because someone is selling them on Ebay for £.!!! These guys in Aldi were allowed to fill their trollies with wipes and nappies last week which they then loaded into their van. You guessed it - Aldi nappies and wipes now on sale on Ebay for a disgusting amount. How the hell is this not illegal  It’s children’s necessities FFS. Ebay have been contacted with no reply, Aldi too. They’re just reaping all the profits from our despair. Do you think the staff will be seeing anything extra in their pay-packet  It is not right. And I’m very happy to say that in contrast - there is so much bloody loveliness coming out of the world too. Facebook groups being set up to help neighbours or vulnerable. I’m social distancing because of chemo and this week, so many people have askedwe need help. I’ve had nappies and hand gel and school books for Ivy delivered - even some flower-seeds to spread in the garden with Ivy. I’ve seen people doing shopping for others and free teaching support being offered and meals being left on doorsteps. I absolutely adore this side of the human race.  I’ve been home-schooling Ivy and although I set out to keep it as ‘schooly’ as I could, I’ve found so many fun activities to do that we both actually enjoy Pizza fractions, writing and then learning all the words to her favourite songs, writing stories and drawing together. We’ve learnt to measure out ingredients on the scales, we’ve learnt about Ireland for St Patrickaposs day and we’ve learnt about bees.There’s so much to learn from once you get going! I’ve been looking here for fun learning games and activities www.brightminds and there’s soooo much!  We’ve also bagged ourselves one of these whoopass Roccbox pizza ovens. OMG I cannot wait to give this a go. They’re portable so you can take them to the beach or the park or wherever you find yourself isolating. And the pizzas only take  seconds to cook - maybe it isn’t the end of the world we’re postponing the wedding because my the forecast for my waistline just got a whole lot bigger! Check them out here.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWith so much new advice and the ever-changing situation with coronavirus, it can be very confusing. Here, Dr Miriam Stoppard answers your questions on everything from self-isolating to risk groups and future plans... We are told deaths relating to coronavirus are people with underlying health problems. Can you clary what these might be  Brenda Tiley, , from Luton Underlying health problems mean any chronic medical condition such as heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, lung disease, kidney disease and liver disease. Cancer and cancer treatments like chemotherapy would also make a person vulnerable. These conditions put a strain on the immune system and make the body less resilient, so you should follow all the advice the Government has given us – e.g. self-isolating, not mixing with people, not going out and not travelling.I’m  and have had three heart attacks but feel healthy, should I self-isolate  I also had Asian flu in , will I still have the antibodies from this and will they protect me against Covid-  Frank Robinson, Swinton, Manchester Despite feeling healthy, your three heart attacks put you in the vulnerable group, so you should self-isolate. I wish I could say having Asian flu in  would protect you but I’m afraid it won’t. Each virus is specic and the only thing that would protect us is a specic vaccination for Covid-. My daughter and daughter-in-law are pregnant. Both are going to work from home but are pregnant women more at risk from this virus and are there any precautions they should be taking  Tina Wallman, , Camberley, Surrey Pregnant women are always considered a special group that requires special attention. In this outbreak, that doesn’t change. In fact, the Chief Medical Officer has put pregnant women into the “vulnerable” group, alongside older people and those that have underlying medical conditions. Soyour daughter and daughter-in-law can, I suggest they self-isolate, stay in their homes, do not mix with other people and do not go outdoors unless necessary.  I’m  with underlying health conditions and I play golf regularly. Should I carry on while avoiding physical contact with playing partners, and avoiding the bar and clubhouse  I enjoy the fresh air and exercise. Peter Sidebotham, Stalybridge, Cheshire It’s great that you play golf to keep fit butyou have underlying health conditions I wouldn’t advise you continue to play – there will always be mixing with other people and you’d be exposed to contaminated surfaces. If there’s any way you could play entirely on your own, without any contact with others, it might work. If this isn’t possible you should stop playing golf altogether for the time being. Those experiencing coronavirus symptoms, such as a cough or fever, should self-isolate for  days.You should stay at homeyou or or anyone in your household has a high temperature or a new and continuous cough - evenitaposs mild. Everyone in your household must stay at home for  days and keep away from others DO NOT go to your GP or hospital.Go to NHS.UK to check your symptoms and follow the specialist medical advice.Only call you canapost get online, you feel like you canapost cope at home, or your symptoms do not get better after the seven days. If you are pregnant you should call you have any concerns about yourself or unborn baby during self-isolation. Pregnant women are advised to contact their midwe, out-of-hours helplines or a maternity team who will provide information on whether you need to go to hospital.  I have mental health disorders including depression, as well as underlying physical health conditions. I’m worried I’ll become more depressed, anxious and vulnerableI self-isolate. Should I stop going out because of coronavirus already, and what can I doI do to help my mental health  Name withheld I’m very sympathetic but with your medical background you’d be well advised to self-isolate and put in place some things that could protect you from loneliness. First, I think you should make a resolution to Skype family or friends at least once a day. Phoning a friend a couple of times each day would help as well. Be more active on social media s and engage with your online friends. Make sure you’re eating a healthy diet, not too much coffee, no alcohol – and get a good night’s sleep.  Is delaying the spread the best policy  Won’t it just prolong people’s anxiety  Ian Mussett Delaying the spread is the strategy to take pressure off the NHS. There are downsides and you describe one of them. I don’t think anyone will relax until we hit a peak of some sort. As it happens, it might not be possible to delay the spread. The Government may have acted too late with restrictive measures. To my mind, we should be going further, as they are in France and Spain, with almost total lockdown. It worked in Wuhan and South Korea. Why aren’t we doing it  I’m  with type  diabetes and on insulin. I’ve had an aorta valve change and I’m on blood thinners. I have high blood pressure too. I’m due to look after my granddaughterher school closes but would that be wise  Alan Bebb, Runcorn, Cheshire With all your medical complaints, you’re vulnerable. I think you should be self-isolating, only going out to shop for food or get your medication. I don’t think it is a good idea to look after your granddaughter, she’ll probably be OK but she might carry the virus to you. The latest advice is not to even meet up with your family. My we and I are in our s and she has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. We have a holiday booked for June . I have paid a deposit and need to pay the balance in April to keep the holiday. Should I  Graham Newnes, Rutland The NHS has stopped advising coronavirus patients to take ibuprofen amid concerns the anti-inflammatory painkiller could only make things worse. A statement read: There is currently no strong evidence that ibuprofen can make coronavirusworse. But until we have more information, take paracetamol to treat the symptoms of coronavirus, unless your doctor has told you paracetamol is not suitable for you. If you are already taking ibuprofen or another non-steroidal anti-inflammatoryon the advice of a doctor, do not stop taking it without checking first. I don’t think so. The Government’s guidelines say because of your age, you and your we fall into the vulnerable category – especially as she suffers from COPD. This means you should self-isolate, not travel and not mix with other people, like eating out in cafés and restaurants. It’s a shame but I think you’ll have to lose your deposit. I’m  and my we is  and she is susceptible to pneumonia. We’ve recently moved and don’t have any friends or relatives close by. In the case of self-isolating, we’ll have no one to help. What should we do  Roger Baber, Bideford, Devon You could stay in touch by phone, Skype, WhatsApp and social media. By doing this you speak to someone every day. You can also keep your family and friends alert to feeling unwell and they can help you get support. You or your family could phone the local council to seethere’s a service that would do your shopping. I know it’s hard because a lot of us are going to feel bereft in the coming months but we just have to do what we can. What’s the best way to help your immune system cope with the virus  Ray Baguely, , Newport There’s nothing you can do from the outside to boost your immune system. The only way would be to have a vaccination so your immune system produced antibodies specically against coronavirus. Exposure to the virus could stimulate your immune system to produce those antibodies itself.  With over-s spending more time at home, will those without access to a garden be advised to take vitamin D  Linda Rachel, , Ipswich With so little sunshine during the winter, people in the older age group are already advised to take mcg of vitamin D every day in the autumn and winter months. For people confined to their homes it’s even more important to follow this advice. My daughter is in her s and expecting her first baby mid-May. She is terried of there not being a bed available when she goes into labour. How can I reassure her on this  Wendy from Cardf

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK could begin trials for a coronavirus vaccine next month, robots are using light beam to zap viruses and air pollution has rapidly dropped. Despite the doom and gloom surrounding the deadly pandemic, more pieces of good news are emerging in the UK and across the world as the fight to stop the virus continues. As of am on Thursday, , people tested positive for Covid- in the UK, and there have been  recorded deaths. And everyone in the UK has now been told to avoid all unnecessary social contact, travel and attending work where possible. But there does appear to be some hope on the horizon... Here are eight feel-good stories that should put a smile on your face. Robots use light beams to zap viruses In China, a robot was used to kill microbes with a zap of ultraviolet light. The incredible test took place in a mock-hospital room, which sees the self-driving machine destroy viruses, bacteria and any other microbes that damage DNA. It uses eight bulbs full of UV-C ultraviolet light, with the machines being distributed across the world - including Europe. Each robot costs , to make, and although it has not yet been proven to kill coronavirus, doctors are confident it will, reports the BBC. It take the robot around  minutes for the robot to clear the room of any viruses. China reports no new cases  On Wednesday, China reported that there have been no new cases of coronavirus for the first time since the outbreak. China has been on lockdown, meaning people can only go outside for food shopping or essential work. Businesses are rewarding NHS staff We cannot thank the NHS staff enough for their hard work during the crisis, and businesses are saying thanks you to them. Companies like Pret, Starbucks, Leon and Dominoaposs are offering the NHS discounts on lunches, hot drinks and even hair cuts just to say a massive thanks too. Air pollution has rapidly dropped As many across the world are working from home and flights being cancelled, the European Space Agencyaposs Copernicus Sentinel-P satellite estimates that the level of nitrogen dioxide in the atmosphere has declined somewhere between  to  per cent in February. This is compared to previous measurements for the same month in , , and . Responses to future pandemics should improve Coronavirus has been an eye opener in terms of how healthcare systems have responded to the pandemic, so a faster global response, better and quicker distribution of testing kits, and more coordinated and coherent public messaging should be expected the next time around. FIFA tournament involving  teams to help football fans League Two side Leyton Orient are helping fans across the globe who miss the beautul game by organising a -team FIFA tournament. The most common symptoms of the coronavirus are: a dry, persistent cougha feverIf you experience these symptoms, you should immediately self-isolate yourself for seven days. It is not necessary to call NHS  unless your symptoms get more severe. Some patients have reported fatigue, headaches, shortness of breath and aches and pains. Sneezing is not a symptom of the coronavirus.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe world is an uncertain place right now as the coronavirus COVID- pandemic takes grip, changing all of our day-to-day lives in an unprecedented way. The news is filled with stories that many of us are finding concerning - and rightly so - and it can feel like everything is a bit gloomy at the moment. But at times like these itaposs important to look for the good things to keep our spirits up, and there has been no shortage of kindness, generosity and hilarity. The UK is coming together to fight back against the deadly disease, looking out for their loved ones, neighbours and complete strangers to make sure they are safe and well. Weaposve had a look at some of the amazing things that have hit the headlines in the last few days. Have you seen an incredible act of kindness  Email webfeatures@trinitymirror. Checking on neighbours Apart from the odd polite hello or awkward small talk when you pick up a parcel, most of us donapost really have much to do with our neighbours. But as soon as people were asked to start self-isolating, residents were reaching out to check people nearby were okay. Kind-hearted folk put notes through doors offering to bring them food shopping or askingthey needed help with anything.  Many have also offered to start regularly calling their neighbours who are unable to go out so they have someone to talk to. Among them was Becky Wass, from Falmouth, Cornwall, who made a print at home template which allows people to tick boxes outlining what help they require.  Children have also been making their parents proud by looking out for elderly people in their area. Seven-year-old Jimmy-Dean Hudson, from Westclfe, Essex, has been out buying toilet roll for people using his pocket money. He then packed it all on to a festival trolley and started making deliveries.  His mum Tracy said: One elderly man in his s was telling us how worried he was and how in the war they didnapost have this panic buying and communities pulled together to help and not be greedy. Iaposm super, super proud of him, and he really has put smiles on many faces. aposaposAll of his family, friends and school teachers are so proud of his kindness. Well-deserved appreciation for our NHS Doctors, nurses, porters, hospital front of house staff and other NHS workers have been putting themselves at risk every single day by going into to work to treat people with coronavirus. Many have taken on extra shts as they do everything they can to treat the symptoms and reassure patients.  In many cases, this has meant theyaposre not able to spend time with their loved ones as theyaposre in an aposat riskapos group. People have taken to social media to thank NHS and other medical stuff for getting up and going to work at this horrible time. Pret, McDonaldaposs and other places are giving all NHS staff free drinks, while some supermarkets are letting them in an hour early so they can get what they need and avoid queues before they go to work. And for supermarket workers, chemists and other aposvitalapos workers Other aposvital workersapos who never normally get recognition or thanks are being appreciated now. Supermarket staff, food delivery drivers, chemists and people who work at factories producing things we need every day have continued going to work while the rest of us stay home.  Just like NHS staff, they have risked getting ill themselves to ensure we have the things we need. There have been many upsetting reports of people being rude to supermarket staff in particular when customers are frustrated by the empty shelves, but the majority of people have been thanking them for going in. The internet being funny While this is obviously an extremely serious issue, itaposs important to have a bit of light relief during dficult and uncertain times. And of course the internet has out done itself. There are countless memes, videos and photos of people adjusting to self-isolating, working from home and social distancing, and they can be the perfect pick-me-up from the worry most of us are currently having. Shopping locally Many small businesses face an uncertain future, especially those in the hospitality sector, as people are asked to stay indoors and not socialise. This has resulted in many people making more of an effort to shop locally to support independent businesses.  Rather than going to supermarkets, many of which have empty shelves, shoppers have been walking down to their local butchers or greengrocers to get fresh produce for dinner. Many independent food shops have also been putting together packages and delivering them to people who are stuck indoors in their area. Catching up with friends Ironically, many of us are actually making more of an effort to chat to our friends since being told weaposre not allowed to see them. Group video call apps have becoming hugely popular as we all catch up with pals.  People have been getting in touch with people they havenapost seen in weeks and enjoying a meal or a glass of wine thanks to the wonders of technology. These penguins got to go on a cute date After the Shedd Aquarium in Chicago closed its doors due to coronavirus, staff decided to let Wellington, Edward and Annie go for a little wander to meet some of the other animals.  Their humans shared photos and videos from their outing on social media, and followers absolutely loved it. The first post, showed Wellington visiting some tropical fish tanks. They said: Penguins in the Amazon ! Some of the penguins went on a field trip to meet other animals at Shedd.  Wellington seemed most interested in the fishes in Amazon Rising! The black-barred silver dollars also seemed interested in their unusual visitor. They followed this up with a clip of bonded pair, Edward and Annie on what people couldnapost help but call a cute date. The adventure continues, they wrote. This morning, Edward and Annie explored Shedd’s rotunda.  They are a bonded pair of rockhopper penguins, which means they are together for nesting season. Springtime is nesting season for penguins at Shedd, and this year is no dferent! The environment People staying indoors has had an extremely positive impact on the environment.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA hotel has sacked and evicted its staff on the spot - with the company pinning the decision on government coronavirus advice. A letter sent to workers at the Coylumbridge Hotel in Aviemore, the Scottish Highlands, outlined workers would get one weekaposs pay in lieu of notice. The hotel, run by Britannia Hotels, has been slammed by politicians and the public after the letter began circulating on social media. It says: Taking the latest government advice, this letter is to confirm that with effect from March  , your employment has been terminated as your services are no longer required. Your final payslip will include all hours worked up to and including your final day, together with any accrued holidays not already taken and one weekaposs pay in lieu of notice. You are asked to vacate the hotel accommodations immediately, ing any company property to John Macfarlane, Hotel Controller before leaving the hotel. I would like to take this opportunity to wish you every success in securing future employment and thank you for your time at Britannia Hotels. It comes just days after the Scottish Government announced financial actions being taken to help businesses across the country affected in the wake of the coronavirus outbreak. The hospitality sector was one of the first to receive special support with a full yearaposs % non-domestic rates relief announced on Wednesday. Finance Secretary Kate Forbes tweeted: Itaposs a tough time for everybody, thataposs why weaposve tried to help the hospitality industry, so itaposs disappointing to see what appears to be the heartless treatment of staff. Drew Hendry - MP for Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey - called the hotelaposs move unacceptable. He also said: It is a worrying time for the hotel trade and urgent support is needed, but everyone is in this emergency together.

We hope and trust that this will not be needed but it is sensible to prepare at this stage. Mirroring NHS plans to re-recruit staff who have left healthcare in a bid to boost staff numbers during the crisis, politan Police Commissioner Cressida Dick said earlier this week that retired police officers and volunteers could be drafted in. She said: We need to be flexible, we are a people organisation and of course itaposs likely as other people are coming into contact with the virus some of my people will as well.

They adhered to strict social-distancing guidelines, sitting two metres away from people, and sanitised their hands twice during the visit. Speaking to a group of handlers, Kate said: Itaposs amazing. Youaposre doing such a great job bringing everyone together and providing that, the support system for the whole public. She hit out at those who are ignoring the governmentaposs Covid- advice, telling : I think it’s really bad. I don’t think people have realised how serious it is. I’m glad I can’t leave my house to witness it first hand. People have been leaving care packages at my door for me.I’ve seen so many lovely posts of people helping others, older people, with care packages. I shared my story as I was sick of people not taking it seriously and still putting themselves or others at risk. Hopefully they’ll be a bit more mindful now. Ingé, who works in a call centre, said doctors told her that she is likely suffering from coronavirus. She was sent home without being tested and told to stay away from others. Her -year-old daughter, Macey, and her cousin have been ordered to self-isolate away from her due to potential exposure to Covid- Ingé said: It started last Thursday, I think. The day after my birthday. I didn’t do anything on my birthday as I’ve just moved into my new house. But I slept for almost  hours and just generally felt really unwell.Then sat I started to get a sore throat and losing my voice. By Sunday afternoon I could barely breathe for coughing. She wheezes with every breath and holds her hand to her chest as she coughs in pain. title: coronavirus nine questions schools closure
story: NewsCoronavirus: Nine questions on schools closure answered with all we know so farEducation Secretary Gavin Williamson said schools will shut at the end of Friday and be shut indefinitely - the Government have not yet put a date on when they may reopenShareCommentsByTristan CorkDan BloomOnline Political EditorDanya Bazaraa:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsSchools in Britain are closing on Friday" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The Government has announced a full shutdown of all schools with the exception of children of key workers as of tomorrow amid the coronavirus pandemic.This announcement came as the Education Secretary said people will be able to go to college and university without having sat GCSE or A-level exams. Gavin Williamson reiterated last nightaposs announcement that no exams will take place this academic year, before the summer term. Askedhe anticipated people still going into higher and further education without undergoing a formal exams process he told Sky: Yes, thataposs right. He added further guidance about how to do this will be published on Friday and talks with school leaders are still ongoing. The Education Secretary said there will have to be an appeals process for any pupil who feels theyaposve been wronged. The Mirror understands it is possible universities could use predicted grades,they resume as normal in September, but this is not confirmed. But what will the schools closure mean for children, parents and families Here is everything we know so far, as reported by Bristol Live.  What schools are involved  The Prime Minister made it clear that all schools would be involved in the shutdown across England, following announcements in Scotland and Wales. Mr Johnson also said that he would be aposexpectingapos childrenaposs nurseries, pre-schools, sixth-forms and colleges to also close their doors.  How long will the shutdown be for  The Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said that schools will shut their gates at the end of Friday and then be shut indefinitely - the Government are careful not to put a time frame or date on when they may reopen. When asked by journalists at the Number  briefing that happened simultaneously, Mr Johnson appeared to rebuff the suggestion, made in Wales and Ireland, that the school closures could be for as long as six months - that Friday would effectively mark the end of the school year, and the summer term after Easter would simply not happen, with schools reopening in September. He said he would hope that schools could reopen before then, but with the coronavirus pandemic rapidly spreading throughout Britain, there is no certainty at all on when they would reopen.  Who will still go to school  The Education Secretary said that schools would remain open for the children of keyworkers, to ensure that people who the country needs to continue to go to work and not worry about childcare, will be able to do so. The Prime Minister said these would be the children of NHS workers, police and emergency services personnel and aposdelivery driversapos who are critical to ensuring the continuing working of the food supply from farm to factory to shops. The Prime Minister said exactly who would be in this list would be revealed this week, before Friday - but there are no firm details as yet, on Wednesday evening.   What about grandparents  There was a specic warning from the Prime Minister that, under no circumstances, children should be now looked after by their grandparents, once they are home from school. That generation of older people are the most vulnerable to coronavirus, and the message from the scientists is that young people and the elderly should be kept apart to avoid older people catching the virus.  What should parents do  One of the key reasons why schools are now being closed is to further ensure that a partial lockdown of society happens. Parents are being asked to look after their children at home, and not leave them with grandparents, and this move is designed to increase the numbers of people who largely withdraw and remain in their homes, to stop the further spread.Most controversially, however, Boris Johnson again held back from making lockdowns and closures of businesses an order - even though all other countries in Europe are pursuing those more severe measures.  What about exams  The Prime Minister confirmed that, given schools will be closed for a considerable time and exams start in May, this yearaposs  GCSEs and A-levels would be scrapped. This does mean that exams will not take place in May and June as planned, but we will make sure that students get the exams they need and deserve, said Mr Johnson. Quite how that happens is unclear, but the most likely explanation will be some kind of grade awarded from coursework already completed, or predictive grades or grades from mock exams.  What about vulnerable children  School children who are classed as vulnerable will be still be allowed to go to school - this includes children who have an EHCP - children with special needs - and children who have a social worker or are in care.  What about Free School Meals  The Prime Minister outlined that they would be rapidly drawing up plans for a voucher scheme for children who are entitled to free school meals - but who will now not be at school to receive it each day - to get that food or support. The details of how exactly this works are yet to be revealed.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA critical care nurse has made a tearful request to the public to stop panic-buying during the coronavirus crisis as key workers are being left without vital nourishment. Her plea comes as chaotic scenes across the country have seen supermarket shelves stripped bare, despite continued insistence from both the government and supermarket bosses that there is enough food. In a heartbreaking video, Dawn Bilbrough, , from York, asks people to just stop taking more food than needed, warning the public itaposs key workers who will be looking after you when youaposre at your lowest. She admits she had a little cry in the supermarket after seeing the fruit and vegetable shelves totally bare. I donapost know how Iaposm supposed to stay healthy. And those people... people are  just stripping the shelves of basic foods. You just need to stop it. Because itaposs people like me that are going to be looking after you when youaposre at your lowest so just stop it. Please!  GMBaposs Susanna Reid said her heart absolutely broke when she heard Dawnaposs emotional plea. A desperate paramedic who had been out saving lives at work was also pictured staring at empty shelves in a Sainsburyaposs.Supermarkets have introduced tighter restrictions on opening hours and item limits in order to tackle the issue.  Tesco, Sainsburyaposs, Asda and Morrisons have been decimated of essential items such as toilet roll, handwash and pasta. Fresh fruit and vegetables, meat, and bread stocks have also been severely raided.There were also violent scenes at an Iceland store in Ilford, east London, earlier this week after an elderly shopper was pushed and shoved out of a packed Iceland store. Customers were seen queuing outside an Aldi even before the doors opened this morning, with most people heading to the loo rolls section straight away - even though the Government has told Britons not to panic buy. Major supermarkets including Sainsburyaposs, Tesco, Aldi and Morrisons have rationed how much of certain products customers can buy. Some stores had scenes of “bedlam” and were stripped bare within  minutes, while staff were abused over queue s and limits on purchases. There were even reports of fights between shoppers and attacks on workers. And some inconsiderate hoarders crashed early-morning slots reserved for the elderly and vulnerable to visit and grab vital supplies.  One social media user said: “I was in a store last night and the shelves were bare. The locusts had descended.” Posting a picture of full shelves yesterday morning, they added: “Your night sht shelf-stackers are heroes.” David Williams of shopworkers’ union Usdaw said: “Shopworkers are on the front line. There are incidents of mass scrabbling when stuff goes on to the shelves. People are working out when the lorries arrive at the stores and are waiting for the products to come out.” In Manchester, -year-old pensioner Marilyn Lundy said she had to leave a branch of Sainsburyaposs empty handed after she found the shelves empty and urged aposgreedyapos shoppers to think twice before filling their trolleys. Kath Blayden, , was looking for paracetamol, long-le milk, loo rolls and tinned pineapple. Staring at the empty painkiller shelf, she said: “I have never seen anything like this. People are being greedy and I think this will only get worse. There’s enough to go aroundthey weren’t so selfish.” At Tesco, Marion Koppel, , said: “I’m trying to do my normal shopping but people are panic buying so much they are making it impossible. “I don’t know what has got into everyone – please just calm down.” Kathryn Hopkins, , from Doncaster said: “Some stores are opening early for pensioners but in our region their free bus pass is not valid until after .am.” The carer said she had tried to do a shop on Wednesday but failed – despite visiting three stores before am.  She said: “It must be a terrible shock to older people who turn up and the shelves are empty. A lot of the basics are nowhere to be seen.” Retired teacher Lesley Thornton said she nearly wept when she saw a couple in their s only manage to get a bag of hotdog buns at a Sainsbury’s in North East London.  The -year-old said: “It was bedlam and makes me feel so frustrated. It was so shocking how empty the store was. The whole frozen section was gone. But I saw kind gestures too, with people handing over goods they’d got to others who were looking for it.” Several supermarket chains have restricted purchases in-demand items like toilet roll, paracetemol and pasta, while others have brought in blanket bans on multiple purchases. Itaposs just one of a number of measures brought in by the nationaposs grocers, as pictures of empty shelves spread through social media like wildfire. Panic buyers have stripped shelves of everything they can - in some cases leaving just ice cream and chocolate Easter eggs - while huge queues snaked around some supermarkets ahead of opening on Wednesday. Currently there are no official limits coming down from the Government, although pressure is growing to impose them, and supermarket bosses insist there is no shortage - simply people over-buying.In the interim, the shops have taken action themselves - limiting customer purchases and opening hours. Competition laws will be temporarily relaxed to allow supermarkets to collaborate in feeding the nation during the coronavirus crisis. Retailers will be able to pool staff, share data on stock levels, and share distribution depots and delivery vans as the Government seeks to ease restrictions under the exceptional circumstances. The temporary relaxation only permits retailers to work together for the sole purpose of feeding the nation as they face a strain from intense demand amid panic buying, ministers said.  The p plastic bag charge will also be waived for online purchases to hasten deliveries, and driversapos hours will be relaxed so more food can be delivered to stores.
